fields.descriptive_line:
Collection of school magazines from Barcombe School, East Sussex, 1918 - 1931, and a number of associated photographs
[Football Team] Photographic postcard showing football team, Barcombe School, 1919 - 1931
[Two men] Photograph showing two men leaning on car, Barcombe School, 1919 - 1931
[Class photograph] Photographic postcard showing children dressed as gollywogs with Father Christmas, Barcombe School, 1919 - 1931
[Girl in costume] Photograph of school class, associated with Barcombe School Magazines, 1918 - 1931
[Boys working] Cut out photograph of girl in Dutch costume, mounted onto cloth, Barcombe School Magazines, 1918 - 1931
[Two girls] Photograph of boys working in garden, Barcombe School Magazines, 1918 - 1931
fields.physical_description:
[Bound volume] Red hard-backed volume with faded blue cloth spine. The cover features a shield enclosing the letters 'BCS', and the spine is labelled 'Barcombe School Magazine' with white letters on a black ground. The dates '1918 - 1931' are written lower down.
The first few pages are of thick dark green card, and contain a newspaper cutting from 'Teacher's World' 1932, marking 21 years of the Barcombe School Magazine. There is a small felt school badge affixed to the following page. 
The rest of the volume comprises 22 issues of the Magazine. Each contains a variety of news and reports about activities in the school, the projects pupils are working on, cartoons and drawings, and contributions from staff and pupils. There are also references to national events, such as the War and Armistice, and how these impact on school life. The Headteacher and editor, Adrian Percy Bishop, signs his editorials 'The Old Fag' and many of the hand-coloured illustrations are signed A.P.B. The magazines are arranged in chronological order, as follows:

No. 1 October 1918 (priced at 1d.)
No. 2 May 1919
Xmas Number December 1919
Peace Commemoration Number July 19th 1919
New Year Number January 1920
Vol 2. No. 2 July 1920
Xmas Number 1920 (price increase to 2d.)
Xmas Magazine 1921
Xmas Number Including Summer Wireless Number 1923
Empire Exhibition Summer Number 1924
Xmas Number 1924
Xmas Number 1925
Cinema Special Number Jan 1926 (raising funds, includes list of available films)
Cinema Number Easter 1926 (includes list of films and donors)
Duplicate of Cinema Special Number Jan 1926
Xmas 1926 Programme, Souvenir and Magazine (cut out photographs on cover)
Letter from Herbert W. Farrow of Barcombe Rectory, 1st March 1927
Xmas Magazine 1927
Empire and Summer Number 1928
Xmas 1928 Magazine
Summer Number July 1929 Special Thanksgiving Issue
Xmas 1929 Magazine
Xmas Magazine 1931 Twenty-first Birthday Number 1910-1931


[Football Team] Black and white photographic postcard showing twelve boys arranged in two rows. Eleven are wearing a football strip of vertical stripes and long socks. The twelth boy is wearing ordinary uniform. They all wear caps bearing the school badge. At some point, the photograph was mounted onto card but has since been pulled off, leaving traces of glue and card on the reverse.
[Two men] Black and white photograph showing two men of middle age, leaning ona large white car, outside a garage. They are relaxed and wearing casual clothes. A large brick house with bay window can be seen over the hedge.
[Class photograph] Black and white photographic postcard showing six children on stage, dancing. They are all wearing striped trousers, dotty bow-ties and black masks with exaggerated large eyes. There is a character dressed as Father Christmas standing behind, holding a crook, and another taller (adult?) figure, wearing 'blackface'. The backdrop is a painted scene of a canal flanked by shop windows. 
[Girl in costume] Black and white photograph of a mixed class of 12 girls and 14 boys, arranged in four rows in front of a brick wall. The boys are mosty wearing collars and ties, and the girls wearing dresses or pinafores. The photograph has been mounted on green card, and has considerable losses around the edges.
[Boys working] Black and white photograph of girl wearing pointed white hat, long striped skirt and clogs, holding knitting. The photograph has been cropped around the shape of her clothes, and has been mounted onto stiff dark green fabric. This has been mounted onto paper and later removed, leaving paper and glue residue.
[Two girls] Black and white photograph showing eleven boys standing in a garden or field, between rows of plants, holding long-handled rakes or hoes. Most are in their shirtsleeves, with ties and caps. They are all looking towards the camera. In the background is a long stone wall and a school building beyond.

fields.public_access_description:
Adrian Percy Bishop became head of Barcombe School in 1918, and assumed responsibility of a school of 128 pupils, and a school magazine. Bishop threw himself into his new role, introducing new ideas such as a prefect system and poultry farming. The magazines chart the next twelve years of the school’s history, reporting on the challenges and triumphs of this small village school.
The magazines offer a rich trove of stories and pictures of sporting events, performances and parades, scholarships, class work and singular events.
Bishop oversaw the production of a wooden War Memorial in 1919, a whole-school visit to the Empire Exhibition at Wembley in 1924, the building of a 200 ft train track in his own house, and a fundraising drive to buy a film projector for the school. 
The magazines are also interesting for their portrayal of other countries, and the use of implicit and explicit racial and gender stereotypes.
1928 saw the children out of school for more than a month, and at least one dying due to the measles epidemic, the King fell worryingly ill, and Bishop’s own father died. After this terrible year, the volume ends on a high note as the Magazine celebrated its twenty-first year in production.
fields.history_note:
Written, printed, collected and bound by Adrian Percy Bishop. 
This collection of volumes was bought by a member of the Guyatt family, probably the donor's sister.
fields.production_note: The volumes were gathered and probably bound at a later date by A P Bishop.
